sn16.2:4.2: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa and Venerable Sāriputta were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn16.2:4.3: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of solitude, went to Venerable Mahākassapa,
sn16.2:4.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn16.2:4.7: “Reverend Kassapa, it’s said that without being keen and prudent you can’t achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
sn16.2:4.8: But if you’re keen and prudent you can achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
sn16.2:5.1: To what extent is this the case?”
sn16.2:5.3: “Reverend, take a mendicant who doesn’t foster keenness by thinking: ‘If unarisen unwholesome qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unwholesome qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen wholesome qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen wholesome qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
sn16.2:6.1: And how are you not prudent?
sn16.2:6.2: Take a mendicant who doesn’t foster prudence by thinking: ‘If unarisen unwholesome qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unwholesome qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen wholesome qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen wholesome qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
sn16.2:6.4: That’s how without being keen and prudent you can’t achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
